After the fall of France in 1940, Messiaen was interned for nine months in the German prisoner of war camp Stalag VIII-A, where he composed his Quatuor pour la fin du temps ("Quartet for the end of time") for the four instruments available in the prison—piano, violin, cello and clarinet.
He was appointed professor of harmony soon after his release in 1941 and professor of composition in 1966 at the Paris Conservatoire, positions that he held until his retirement in 1978.

Olivier Eugène Prosper Charles Messiaen was born at 11:00 on 10 December 1908 at 20 Boulevard Sixte-Isnard in Avignon, France, into a literary family.
In 1918 his father returned from the war and the family moved to Nantes.
Messiaen entered the Paris Conservatoire in 1919, aged 11.
In 1924, aged 15, he was awarded second prize in harmony, having been taught in that subject by professor Jean Gallon.
In 1925 he won first prize in piano accompaniment, and in 1926 he gained first prize in fugue.
In 1925 he won first prize in piano accompaniment, and in 1926 he gained first prize in fugue.
After studying with Maurice Emmanuel, he was awarded second prize for the history of music in 1928.
Messiaen gained first prize in organ playing and improvisation in 1929.
After a year studying composition with Charles-Marie Widor, in autumn 1927 he entered the class of the newly appointed Paul Dukas.
Despite his grief, he resumed his studies, and in 1930 Messiaen won first prize in composition.
His public début came in 1931 with his orchestral suite Les offrandes oubliées.
In the autumn of 1927, Messiaen joined Dupré's organ course.

In 1943, Messiaen wrote Visions de l'Amen ("Visions of the Amen") for two pianos for Yvonne Loriod and himself to perform.
Messiaen visited the United States in 1949, where his music was conducted by Koussevitsky and Leopold Stokowski.

Birdsong and the 1960s
When in 1952 Messiaen was asked to provide a test piece for flautists at the Paris Conservatoire, he composed the piece Le merle noir for flute and piano.
He took this development to a new level with his 1953 orchestral work Réveil des oiseaux—its material consists almost entirely of the birdsong one might hear between midnight and noon in the Jura.

From this period onwards, Messiaen incorporated birdsong into all of his compositions and composed several works for which birds provide both the title and subject matter (for example the collection of thirteen pieces for piano Catalogue d'oiseaux completed in 1958, and La fauvette des jardins of 1971).

Messiaen's first wife died in 1959 after a long illness, and in 1961 he married Loriod.
Messiaen's first wife died in 1959 after a long illness, and in 1961 he married Loriod.
In 1962 he visited Japan, where Gagaku music and Noh theatre inspired the orchestral "Japanese sketches", Sept haïkaï, which contain stylised imitations of traditional Japanese instruments.
Works performed included Réveil des oiseaux, Chronochromie (commissioned for the 1960 festival) and Couleurs de la cité céleste.
His reputation as a composer continued to grow and in 1959, he was nominated as an Officier of the Légion d'honneur.
In 1966 he was officially appointed professor of composition at the Paris Conservatoire, although he had in effect been teaching composition for years.

sentences: Olivier Eugène Prosper Charles Messiaen (UK: , US: ; French: [ɔlivje mɛsjɑ̃]; 10 December 1908 – 27 April 1992) was a French composer, organist, and ornithologist who was one of the major composers of the 20th century.
He was appointed organist at the Église de la Sainte-Trinité, Paris, in 1931, a post held for 61 years until his death.

After the fall of France in 1940, Messiaen was interned for nine months in the German prisoner of war camp Stalag VIII-A, where he composed his Quatuor pour la fin du temps ("Quartet for the end of time") for the four instruments available in the prison—piano, violin, cello and clarinet.
Messiaen later said this sequence of poems influenced him deeply and he cited it as prophetic of his future artistic career.
His interests included the recent music of French composers Claude Debussy and Maurice Ravel, and he asked for opera vocal scores for Christmas presents.
The following year Pierre Messiaen gained a teaching post in Paris.
After a year studying composition with Charles-Marie Widor, in autumn 1927 he entered the class of the newly appointed Paul Dukas.
That year he first heard a gamelan group, sparking his interest in the use of tuned percussion.
In the autumn of 1927, Messiaen joined Dupré's organ course.

In 1947 he taught (and performed with Loriod) for two weeks in Budapest.
Beginning in summer 1949 he taught in the new music summer school classes at Darmstadt.

While he did not employ the twelve-tone technique, after three years teaching analysis of twelve-tone scores, including works by Arnold Schoenberg, he experimented with ways of making scales of other elements (including duration, articulation and dynamics) analogous to the chromatic pitch scale.
He took this development to a new level with his 1953 orchestral work Réveil des oiseaux—its material consists almost entirely of the birdsong one might hear between midnight and noon in the Jura.
In 1966 he was officially appointed professor of composition at the Paris Conservatoire, although he had in effect been teaching composition for years.

Further honours included election to the Institut de France in 1967 and the Académie des beaux-arts in 1968, the Erasmus Prize in 1971, the award of the Royal Philharmonic Society Gold Medal and the Ernst von Siemens Music Prize in 1975, the Sonning Award (Denmark's highest musical honour) in 1977, the Wolf Prize in Arts in 1982, and the presentation of the Croix de Commander of the Belgian Order of the Crown in 1980.
In the summer of 1978, Messiaen retired from teaching at the Paris Conservatoire.

sentences: Messiaen said, "I am able to allow myself the greatest eccentricities because to her anything is possible."
Messiaen had a great admiration for the music of Igor Stravinsky, particularly the use of rhythm in earlier works such as The Rite of Spring, and his use of orchestral colour.
This led Messiaen to use rhythmic cells that irregularly alternate between two and three units, a process that also occurs in Stravinsky's The Rite of Spring, which Messiaen admired.

His evocations of birdsong became increasingly sophisticated, and with Le réveil des oiseaux this process reached maturity, the whole piece being built from birdsong: in effect it is a dawn chorus for orchestra.
